ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, Good question about starting from a seed genome.  One idea I can think of is to start not only with the seed genome but also with the archive of behavior

Jeff,

Good question about starting from a seed genome.  One idea I can thi=
nk
of is to start not only with the seed genome but also with the archive
o=
f behavior characterizations that accompanies it from a prior run of
novelt=
y search, assuming that's where it comes from.  Of course if the
behavior c=
haracterization has changed in a fundamental way, that won't
work, but it's=
 possible in some cases.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jcl=
une@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Petar (or is it Peter?)-
> 
> That is an ambitious p=
roject, and I look forward to seeing it progress.
> 
> One quick question: =
you mention below that you changed two things
between
> the code you releas=
ed and your 100% gait-producing setup. You
switched to
> zero-G and you swi=
tched to looking for oscillations. Do I have that
right?
> 
> Out of curios=
ity, did you try just searching for oscillations but not
> switching to zer=
o-G? Alternately, did you try taking some of your
walkers
> from zero-G and=
 then turning gravity on?
> 
> This raises an interesting question in novel=
ty search research: how
can you
> use a good seed organism to kick-start a =
process? If you have a
walker that
> moves a few steps away and then falls,=
 it seems that the beginning of
> novelty search will simply reward the eas=
y discovery of all the points
> around center. So, instead of working on th=
e walker's genome and moving
> farther out, it will revert to producing all=
 the 'fall left', 'fall
right',
> etc since that is the low hanging fruit. =
Once all that low hanging
fruit is
> gone, the genome of the walker is prob=
ably lost. There would be a
chance of
> recovering it, I guess, if you peri=
odically resurrected archive
individuals
> when the population is stagnatin=
g. It may even be interesting to try to
> resurrect those individuals whose=
 end-point is furthest from those
points
> currently being visited by the p=
opulation.
> 
> Just thinking out loud...
> 
> Very cool stuff. I'd love to=
 see the zero-G guys if you can post em!
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune=

> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> 
> jclune@...
> 
>=
 
> 
> 
> > From: petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>
> > Reply-To: "ne=
at@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > Date: Thu, 26 Jun 2008 16:04=
:37 -0000
> > To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > Subject=
: [neat] Re: New file uploaded to neat
> > 
> > Hi Jeff, 
> > 
> > I am gla=
d that you like my program and enjoy it! :)
> > 
> > I know it would be coo=
l to browse the archive, or have an external
> > routine that queries the a=
rchive by different criteria to show me
> > what was achieved during the ru=
n, but this program now is actually a
> > stepping stone for another resear=
ch project I have, evolving leaky-
> > integrator substrates by HyperNEAT c=
ombined with evolving the
> > substrate itself, all used in one Alife simul=
ation of mass-spring
> > creatures, sensing collision and reacting by contr=
acting the springs.
> > And all this with Novelty Search searching for new =
and new behaviors.
> > I believe that this is a pretty serious test of how =
far complexity
> > can go in such open-ended domain. I can later mix it wit=
h fitness
> > search once a good population has evolved, on objectives
> > =
like "swimming". 
> > 
> > Let me mention about one interesting experiment =
I made with the NS
> > NEVH. I restricted the substrate connectivity so tha=
t output->output
> > connections are not queried. Then I made the environme=
nt to 0 gravity
> > and removed the ground plane. The behavior characteriza=
tion was
> > changed like this. The behavior data is a vector of 15 doubles=

> > representing the outputs. Each time an output oscillates (going to
> >=
 +treshold and then -treshold, or vice versa), its corresponding place
> > =
in the vector is incremented.
> > So the vector is actually counting how ma=
ny oscillations the outputs
> > did during the lifetime. A substrate oscill=
ating with high frequency
> > is very far in the behavior space. Different =
outputs oscillating are
> > counted too. The behavior distance metric is th=
e eucledian distance
> > between these 15-D vectors.
> > 
> > So novelty se=
arch now has to find new ways to oscillate the entire
> > body, to do repea=
ting movements. In all the runs, Novelty Search with
> > HyperNEAT finds wa=
lking gaits 100% of the time, in the first 1000
> > evaluations. There are =
also swimming gaits and all kind of stuff (I
> > saw one individual actuall=
y dancing :))
> > 
> > So what was stopping it from walking before, is the =
gravity. Keeping
> > balance on one leg and trying to walk at the same time=
 turns out to
> > be very hard task. One environmental constraint that woul=
d be useful
> > to make it walk is, when only one foot has stepped on the g=
round,
> > stick that foot to the ground. So the chance the humanoid to fal=
l is
> > minimized. 
> > 
> > As for the novelty search stagnation, where g=
etting new behaviors
> > becomes hard, the population begins to do somethin=
g like a random
> > probing anything that is not the same stuff. Then it be=
gins to rely
> > entirely on mutation to get out somehow.
> > 
> > Peter
> =
> 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> =
I finally borrowed a windows machine from someone and looked at
> > this. I=
t's
> >> really fun to watch! I am leaving it running overnight to see what=

> > happens.
> >> So far the best I have seen has been about a five mini-s=
tep shuffle
> >> backwards...although I have seen a few three mini-step for=
ward
> > shuffles.
> >> 
> >> Can you post either the genome and or a movie=
 of the best org
> > you've seen so
> >> far? 
> >> 
> >> I second the noti=
on that it would be cool to browse the archive,
> > especially
> >> if you =
could choose archive members to view based on max distance
> > from 0,0
> >=
> or something like that.
> >> 
> >> It might help you to visualize things =
if you added another viewing
> > mode that
> >> put a dot in the 3D viewer =
for every x,y,z coordinate in the
> > archive (one
> >> color) and in the c=
urrent population (another color).
> >> 
> >> Watching this also makes me w=
onder about the population losing its
> > gradient
> >> and disengaging. He=
re is the potential concern (and I think mattias
> > and ken
> >> discussed=
 this already): Once all the easy to access points are
> > found, if
> >> m=
ost of the orgs are not getting somewhere new, they will all have
> > equal=

> >> fitnesses and the search will not be focused on the outside edge.
> >=
 Do you
> >> think this is happening (and might this be why David mentioned=
 that
> > he saw a
> >> lot of repeats toward the end)? The visualization I=
 just proposed
> > might help
> >> on this front. Do the points added in th=
e archive tend to be
> > further and
> >> further away from 0,0....or is it=
 just filling in the spaces in the
> > nearby
> >> vicinity? 
> >> 
> >> De=
spite these concerns/suggestions, it is very fun stuff to look
> > at...and=

> >> its exciting that you are hybridizing these ideas so quickly and
> > =
testing
> >> them. 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >> 
> >> Dig=
ital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> >> 
> >> jclune@
> >> 
> >>=
 
> >> 
> >>

ubject: [neat] Re: New file uploaded to neat

> >>> Wow, this looks r=
eally cool Petar.  I thought it would be awhile
> >>> before we saw HyperNE=
AT and novelty search combined.  I ran it
> > while I
> >>> was working on =
other stuff for a bit over 50,000 evaluations,
> > checking
> >>> in on it =
periodically.  The behavioral diversity was really
> >>> impressive: I got =
guys that were taking baby steps and guys that
> > were
> >>> doing yoga po=
ses (I swear one of them did "the chair"), although
> > there
> >>> were st=
ill a good number of repeats, especially near the end
> > (falling
> >>> on=
to theirs knees seemed pretty common).  No one that I saw had a
> > good
> =
>>> walking gait, but I guess it's possible that one could have when I
> >>=
> wasn't watching, perhaps we need an option to browse the archive.
> > I'm=

> >>> curious about a few things, if you wouldn't mind sharing:
> >>> 
> >=
>> -What did you use as a novelty metric?  It's seems like there are
> > a
=
> >>> number of viable options here.
> >>> 
> >>> -What do the nodes on the=
 substrate mean, and are they just on a
> > flat
> >>> plane?  I used your =
older version when it was first released, and
> > if I
> >>> remember right=
 the two on the left are inputs and the stuff on the
> >>> right is various=
 joints, but I wanted to make sure.
> >>> 
> >>> -Similarly, what do you us=
e as the 5th input on the CPPN?
> >>> 
> >>> Thanks,
> >>> David D'Ambrosio=
